The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaxa (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5p.m. for Prt Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5p.m. for Tor (for Sinai, Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: INDIAN UNREST.
div.p: The news from India for some weeks past has been read by those who take an interest in the welfare of that country with mingled feelings. It is distressing to observe that a part of the result of the policy which lias tried to give Western instruction to all who were willing te receive it, has been to create a class of writers and speakers Whose one aim is to overthrow the Government that has made their existence possible. It is distressing also to see that the class of writers and speakers just described have attained to a considerable influence aver a portion of the Hindu population. On the other had, there is some satisfaction to be derived from the fact that the Indian Government has not by the knowledge that these conditions exist been scared into any hurried departure from its ideals or from its methods of government, and that even when the preachers of anarchical doctrines have led their hearers into excess there has been no rush into repression, but only a moderate and sparing use of powers, which the Government has long possessed but rarely used, of removing to safe places the inciters to disorder. The recent steps taken by the Indian Government, happily with the entire concurrence of the Government at home, have had perhaps a more salutary effect than might have been produced by a wholesale display of force or by a severe course of repression. The campaign of mispresentation and invective, accompanied by demonstrations of disloyalty and attempts at terrorism, together with the organis ed boyeott, whieh began in Bengal has made its way into the Punjab, to the great disgust of the loyal Mohammeddans. The removal of a few leaders to distant places of seclusion has had a quieting effect and the deportation of another agitator from Amritsar, announced last week, will help to convince the others that their occupation is not for ever to be tolerated. The Circular sent by the Indian Government to local Governments pointing out the messures that may feasonably be taken to, prevent schools and colleges from being nurseries of sedition seems also to be a step in the direction of the restoration of tranquility. Very welcome, too, is the resolution reported this morning empowering local Governmerits to pro: secute newspapers that, publish articles inciting to disturbance. The natural tendency of observers at home in presence of sedition in India is to urge the Indian Government to put it down with a strong hand. That is a tendency to which we do not wish to yield. The Indian Government is better informed than any observers hire, and is mote keenly aware of the possible consequence of its action than can be any critics in this country. It is not only informed but responsible. Accordingly the duty of good citizens in this country is to uphold the Indian Government in every possibie way, even to the extent of remembering that every human Government is liable to make mistakes and therefore of abstaining from microsdopic criticism of its action.

One of the chief difficulties of any Government, which like that of Great Britain is organised upon democratic principles in so far that it is responsible to a Parliament, is that in dealing with the affairs of distant countries, specially of countries of different society and speech from our own, there is always the possibility of criticisms made upon it in the ordinary course of Parliamentary life being misinterpreted at the other end of the tele graph wire. If one party is in office, and the other party, being in opposition, discusses freely the executive or other acts of the Government, persons at a distance may infer that this country is divided and therefore has no strong will. Such an impression, if it should be produced or encouraged in India just now, would be most unfortunate. We venture to hope that it will not be produced. It is fortunate that the Viceroy of India appointed by the late Government has the confidence of their successors. It is fortunate that the responsibility to Parliament for the government of India is in the hands of Mr Morley, in whose character and ability both parties have complete confidence. There are, of course, many who do not agree with some of Mr. Morley's political theories, theories which we have often had occasion to criticise. But Mr. Morley is a worker, a great student, an administrator of more than ordinary power. There is no fear in his case of a failure to grasp the nature of a situation, or of a weakness in decision or in tenacity of purpose. His conduet and that of the Government of India in dealing with the agitation and the disturbanees in India will hardly bo the subject of criticism from the Opposition. It would, we venture to think, be a misfortune if any embarrassement were caused him by lack of sympathy from among those who are as a rule the supporters of the present Government.

The doctrine now taught by some of those Hindus who a few years ago were represented as the advocates of the gradual introduction of representative methods and a constitutional system into India, is that of overthrow of the British Government as soon as possible, by the plan of passive resistance and of a strike of all natives in Government employ, and if that fails then by conflict. While such a theory is preached in India it appears to us that no Englishman, whatever his theory of Government may be, can without injuring his country and India; express sympathy with any form of Indian propaganda. In doing so he would be playing with fire. In India it is the class that has had the benefit of European instruction that expresses extreme doctrines, and observers in England should bear in mind that these doctrines are preached to people unaccustomed to political debate and still more to that political action which is part of the daily life of the people of this country. Those who would support the Indian Government in measures for restricting the liberty of the Indian Press to spread denunciations of the British administration do so on the ground that the conditions of India are not those of England. Here there are always newspapers on both sides. There is no danger of the cause of law having no exponents. But in India the case is very different. Of those who have had a literary training perhaps the pick are in Government employ or in such other employment as is not consistent with their being journalists. But those whose literary instruction has not opened for them a career in the public service are exposed to the temptation, not always resisted, of seeking influence and notoriety by attacks on the Government. In a country where instruction, even after many years of Government effort to spread it, is the privilege of a very few, the Government is not only entitled but bound to exercise some supervision to prevent its being misused. No doubt the great powers possessed by a Government like that of India could conceivably be misused. Everyone will admit that in theory. But in practice the character of the Indian Government and its splendid tradition of equity and tolerance are a great guarantee, and to those people in this country who favour the development of self-government in India, as elsewhere, there could be no better guarantee that the Indian Government will not misuse the powers which it possesses for dealing with sedition and disturbance than the character of Mr. Morley. It is not likely that he will err on the side of unnecessary severity.

div.head: Hashish Seizuro.
div.p: The Custom House officials at Port Said have seized 1,500 kilos of hashish, which were being passed through in 17 cases as paper.

div.head: Cotton Worm.
div.p: 46 employees have just been engaged by the Ministry of the Interior, in order to super-intend operations for the destruction of cotton worm.

div.head: Bakers Strike.
div.p: On Saturday morning several bakers went out on strik but, on most of their demands being satisfactorily met, they shortly resumed work.

div.head: Found Drowned.
div.p: On Friday morning the body of a native was taken from the Nile at Shoubra by the Polic, who are of opinion that death is due to an accident, as the body bears no traces of violence.

div.head: Fraudulency.
div.p: A native man of Alexandria, who was out of work, has been obtaining money by present-ing himself at various houses on the pretence that he was engineer of the Municipality sent to inspect the buildings. He is now in the hands of the police.

div.head: Small Pox in Dongola.
div.p: The efficient measures taken by the Medical Department in order to stamp out the small-pox from Dongola Province, have been crowned with success. No new cases have developed, and the Province has been completely rid of this disease.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: The following furth r cases of bubonic plague are reported :-5 cases and 1 death in hos-pital at Beni-Mazar : 1 death in hospital at Mellawi ; 2 deaths at Abnoub, 2 admissions and 2 deaths in hospital at Esneh. 47 cases still remain under treatment.

div.head: Price of Gum.
div.p: The prices of gum at Dueim and Omdurman have gone up very hgih. The "Sudan Times" learns that the price has reached 107 P.T. per cantar. This rise is attributed to the shortage of arrivals due to the approach of the rainy season, and to the rise in the prices of the article in Europe. In London, gum is fetching 38s. per cwt.

div.head: Severe Sandstorm.
div.p: A sand-storm of great density swept over Khartoum on the 2nd inst. About 5 o'clock a great schene was witnessed to the south east. An immense mountain seemed moving towards the city. In a few minutes, the whole place was enveloped in darkness, so thick that lamps had to be lighted. The habub, however, was of short duration, and at 5.15 it was almost all over. A continuous habub of less ambition character has been blowing all this morning.

div.head: Hotel Villa Margherita.
div.p: Our readers will find in the advertisement columns of to-day's issue a notice of the above hotel which is delightfull situated on the drive at San Stefano, opposite the station and next to the Casino and bathing establish-ment. The restaurant, with its excellent cuisine opens in a week's time and we should mention that it is available for non-residents as well as the visitors at the sea, and is an ideal place to spend the summer months.

div.head: Cyprus Carob Crop.
div.p: The Italian Consular Agent at Larnaca reports, according to the Moniteur Officiel du Commerce, that the Cyprus carob yield in 1906 is considered to have been one of the most remarkable of late years. The total yield of th eisland is stated as 300,000 Aleppo can-tars, or about 69,000 tons. In January las ten steamers were loading in all 15,000 tons fo rEngland, six sailing vessels were to take 2,500 tons of caroubs to France, and five others with 2,400 tons were to sail for Spain, while another 500 tons were destined for Italy. He adds that, in spite of large stocks the prices remained at 9.50 frs. to 9.75 frs. the 100 kilos f.o.b.

div.head: The Tour Eiffel.
div.p: An excellent show is at present being given at the Tour Eiffel, which is a music-hall well worthy of the support of those of our readers who are so inclined. Among the best turns we have noted the Sisters Florence, three English artistes who sing well and dance excellently Miss Violet Esdaile is an Australian singer and dancer of considerable ability, and Miss Hanny Grey delights the audience with excel-lent selections from the popular songs of the English music-hall stage. Among those of other tongues, M. Riso-Riso takes a good place as an Italian comic, and Mile. Lyda Osman, an old Cairo favourite, is as attractive as ever. Mlle. Gaby has an excellent voice and gives every night three selections from the best known operas and often earns an encore, while the Barberis are very popular duettistes and make a splendid "turn." Among the debutsadvertis-ed for the near future are Mlles. Rostow, Phalene, Hedy-Dedy, Marcelle de Vierg, Katy, and Marcelle d'Olga.

div.head:
EGYPTS BENEFACTOR
ENGLAND'S GRATITUDE.
AMUSING "NATIONALIST" REPLY.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel appears to be very' greatly enraged by the granting of the freedom of the City of London to Lord. Cromer asa mark'of the high esteem in whicli his work in Egypt is 'held at home. Ina remarkable and amusing article the "Egyptian - ird" takes Reuter's Agency and the pondents of the Occupation Press to ia for having emphasised the honour and significance of such a conferment. The same paper insinuates that no mention was made of a similar conferment on Lord Lister, but we humbly beg to refer the. writer of the article in, question to the issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" of Thorsday the 6th inst. The repro- duetion of the article will give further proof to our readers abroad that Mustapha Kamel can hardly be actuated in his writings by a reasonable spirit, for no reason for such an outburst of rage could be offered by any of his supporters. It is: somewhat amusing that the artidle insists upon the omission of Lord Lister's namein the telegram announcing the honour to Lord Cromer as being wilful, whereas the heading 1eads "careless omission," We might also remark that Mustapha Kamel has at times taken pains to point out that it was only Lord Cromer's policy which he attacked, while this article shows extreme personal venom. The following is the text in extenso:—
"It will be remembered what a fuss was made over Lord Cromer's being offered the freedom of the City of London.

"Reuter's Agency and the correspondents of the Occupation papers wired in magnificent enthusiastic terms, the glorious news of the unparalleled honou conferred upon the great Earl of Cromer by the stupifying generosity of the City Corporation.

"And Cromerites were thunderstruck. They remained bouche-bes. They gushed all over with pride and felt patriotic-——-Cro-merrily' pa- triotic—and cheered the, ex-pro-Consul and praised the Lord that they were Imperialists

"But what neither Reuter's Agency nor the correspondents of the Occupation papers stated —they even shunned it as doth a mule a tin- can—was that Lord Cromer:was not the only Lord whom it was proposed to hononr in the way.
"Of course they did not state so. It would have detracted from the importance of the unparallelism, which they wished to impress upon the Egyptians.

"So naturally, with the remarkably fine, gentlernanly sense of impartiality which cha- racterises the Imperialist bogey press, they left the other Lord out in the cold, and passed over the honor conferred upon him with com- prehensible though not exactly justifiable disdain,
"Who was the other Lord ?

"Ps — Lord Lister—a somebody, perhaps a nobody in Cromerite eyes, but. still a greater man thar the Earl of Cromer was the genius whom the City Corporation offered in the first place, thie freedom of the City of London.

"Tt is/excusable perhaps, this omission on the part of Reuter's Agency and.the correspondents of the Imperislist, justice-loving press. Because, blinded by: their fatuity for Lord Cromer, they ignore the existence of all other Lords.

"We are sorry to-day to have to throw a backet of cold water upon their rejoicing and at the same time to reveal to the impartial members of Egyptian society to what moral extremes the Imperialist press can go when bent upon furthering imperialism regardless of the colour or nature of the means they employ.

"Lord Lister, with Guthrie and Pasteur one of the greatest 'saviours of humanity; Lord Lister, the propagator 'of antiseptic surgery ; Lord Lister the eminent surgeon who had saved the lives of thousands, hundreds of thonsands of doomed invalids and_ sufferers ; Lord Lister—well Lord Lister dwindled away 'at-the shadow of nothing beside the gigantic hero of Denshawai, beside the man who would not'commutate an unjust death sentence, who officially insulted the religion of three hundred million souls as might have done a fanatic missionary.
"Dwindles away to nothing/Ab, time will say !

"'o-day, and inspite of Reuter's agency and the correspondents of the' Occupation press, the gratitude of milions repays Lord Lister for his deeds, whereas a few stock-brokers, bondholders speculators, financiers and ¢a- pitalists—together with their officially trampet- press organs—are the only grateful debtors of the Earl of Cromer.

"And to think that the /reédom of a city has been given to a man who has become eminent in Imperialist arenas because he refused to give freedom toa country! Itis the non plus ultra of political irony."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. C. Dickson, sub-governor of the Nation-al Bank, is going on leave on the 22inst for three months
Mr. R. Finzi, manager of the Banque d'E-scompte et de Rapport, is leaving for Italy at the end of this month
The death has occurred suddenly at Cairo of Mrs. Lina Spitzer, the wife of Mr. Arthur Spitzer, in her 31st year.

div.head:
LECHAT-GANEM CASE.
HEARING CONCLUDED.
div.p: oa consequence of the great im to the Lechat-Ganem assault. case atcrs extravagant articles, which appeared in many of the local newspapers, the public attendance was enormous at the second hearing of this case, which took place on Thursday morning at 10-80 a.m. before the French Consul, Mr. Paul de Reffye, who was assisted in his difficult task by Messrs: Favenc and' Bianchi, After many witnesses had been called, Maitre Widal, counsel for the plaintif rose, and, in the course of « lengthy address, eloquently referred to the evils and discomforts. attributable to hasty tempers. He further pointed out that, the-opprobrious and insulting terms, which his client, Mr. Cheki-Ganem, is alleged to have used towards the defendant, were tot proyed, and that according to the evidence, no, provocation whatever had been given to justify so brutal an attack. During his M. Widal frequently appealed with great. ex- citement to the President, for the of the Tribunal, stating that it was quite possible for him to proceed, while the defendant was permitted to insult him, The. President, however, was unable to admit thatany cause for complaint had been established and held that the case must continue.. M. Widal, who was evidently much upset by this contretemps, soon after took his seat.

In reply to M. Widal, M. Guithaumon delivered a stirring defence. He related in detail and, with many humorous remarks, the scene which ocedrred' at the theatre, and expressed his hearty approval'of the manly way in which his client, at last goaded beyond endurance, had endeavoured to .put a stop to the insinuations and abuse to which he and his wife had been exposed. He then proposed to read a letter to the Court, which Mr. Ganem had written in April last to Mme. Lechat, but, by request of she plaintif, who objected on the grounds that he did not desire the members of his family to be dragged into the case, the President ordered the letter to be withdrawn. In short, M. Guilhaumen pleaded: great o vocation and suggestted that his client's tions were, under the circumstances, justifiable M. Padoa then replied in a few well chosen words, and, after much heated - discussion between counsell the case was eventually brought toa close, Judgement was deferred.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras el Tin palace from Montazah this morning. His Highness will preside over the council of Ministers to be held on Thursday.

div.head:
THE HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
INTERVIEW WITH IZZET PASHA.
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of the "Indian Daily Telegraph" has. interviewed Izzet Pasha the progress Hedjaz railway: Inzet Pasha -stated~ that %£72,800,000 hed. been collected and another £71,500,000 would be required to the 180 syilen frop Dessaboon to Méepac tyro: sums work outa cost of about £3,600. sterling' per milo of fine, Izzet Pasha said that part of the country was.-very difficult, and 'at the present time food for the..workmen' 'and all' materials had to be: carried a, distance of 580 miles Five thousand soldiers. were at work on the line, drawn:from the 4th, Sth, and 6th | Army and their employment, 'substan- tially reduced the Jabonr bill.' 'The " whole thing had been conducted honestly and above | board,'and no railway expert could accuse the of extravagance. being forward in the hope "that "by 1908, the anniversary of his Ma- jesty's accession, a train might be steam! men it to Medina, Between that sacred -spot Mecca' the country was mountainons, and there would be difficulty about water, but they" hoped'to cover the 280 miles between the two holy'cities in less than two years. As they pushed farther south thes sbimats was 'against them, and they could not expect the same amount of work from men as in' .colder climes, During the year 5,000 pilgrims had been 'carried from Damascus to Tamboul, 'whence they proceedéd by launch to Medina, the whole journey oceupying only 12 instead of 85 days, ' and the railway ticket costing £5 2s. o¥ about jd. per mile. In answer toa question, Izzet Pasha said there. was at present no idea of prolonging the railway to Jeddah to aid Indian pilgrims, or to 'Hodeidahy:as a strategic point to reinforce the garrison of Yemen.

div.head:

THE GYPSUM TRADE
div.p: The French Consul-General at Alexandria, in a report published in tho "Moniteur Officiel da neat of 2 May. gives the. following as thechiefcountries of production: —Cyprus=tons 20,461: — Austria-Hungary - ton® 1: France, tops 882: Italy, tons 10: Turkey, tong.t, 792., Marseilles plaster is classed, he says," "in three qualities ;—-White, extra superfine, at 40 to 45 fos. white, 'ordinary, at 30 to; 33'fres': and Grey, at 27 to 80 fros, delivered Tob. Alexandria. Cyprus plaster, fetches 18 to 19 fess per ton, Customs duties are &* per -cent,-ad valorem, and a further'l . per cent. stiould be added for. wharfage dues ete." Until-1886-1887 it appears that this. article,' imported into Egypt, came almost exclusivity allots on the qu ies France, but since then factories havé hequ started at Limassol and Larnaca, which haye succeeded in delivering, to the Egyptian market an excellent quality. of white plaster of very fine grain, the price of which is as stated aber. 'Theshipments are made in small sailing versols at a freight charge of 5 to 7 franos the ton, Marseilles' plaster is not so much in. Marseilles is inferior to the corresponding quality from Cypris, although costing more ; ibtléss owing to the difference in freight.

the manufacture of plaster in, Egypt has had some development, we' are told, since it wag taken up by Enropeans.- But it is said to be liable to flake. 'off, and therefore does' not offer a favourable surface for painting. Gyp-- sum from other countries is therefore preferably used for the finishing coats.

div.head: WEATHER REPORT
div.p: The Survey Department, havé issued the' following report onthe weather of May :— The chief feature of the weather in Egypt during May has been a remarkable absence of those depressions which appear from. time to time in the Mediterranean and give tise, to Khamsin weather at this time of the year The only period during which conditions.were. at all unsettled was from the 4th. to the 7th; This was:a time of low. pressure over 'Lower Egypt, but Khamsin conditions 'were not experienced except in Alexandria on the morning of the 6th. Lightning was seen "in Alexandria on the 6th. and -in Cairo on the 6th. and 7th. 'The close of the disturbance was marked by light rain at Alexandria and Cairoy |. a not unusnal phenomenon at this season. 'For the remainder of the month conditions were undisturbed and accordingly the average atmospheric pressure in Egypt was somewhat higher than the normal arid the avérage tem- perature somewhat lower, There were no sudden changes of wind or temperature, nor were |. there any showers recorded with the exception of: those mentioned above. In the Sidan te summer 'distribution of presstire which ' to appear in April was not established " antl considerably later. The permanent, tise. af the Blue Nile was soniewhat late.

div.head:
SABA PASHA'S RECORD.
HENNIKER-HEATON'S TRIBUTE
div.p: Mr. Henniker Heaton, M.p., writes as follows to the "Times"

On Saturday next his Excellency Saba Pasha, after 35 years' service, and over 20 years Postmaster-General of Egypt, retires from the service for a well-earned rest. The record of his services shows that he is one of the most progressive Postmaster-General in the world. The post-office gives an excellent indica-tion of the progress of a country. Saba Pasha has just issued his last annual report and in it he gives statistics showing the marvellous growth of the Egyptian Post Office. Egypt is one of the two countries in the world that have proclaimed universal penny postage, the other being New Zealand. From January 1, 1887, when Saba Pasha took over postal administra-tion of Egypt, the correspondence has quintup-led. In 1886 the number of letters dealt with was 12,695,000, and in 1906 the number had increased to 58,800,000. The tax (postage) on letters from Egypt to the United Kingdom was reduced on December 15, 1905, to five mil-liemes = one penny. In consequence, the number of letters exchanged with the United Kingdom and British colonies in 1906 increased by 60 per cent. He hopes and believes that universal penny postage will be carried at the next Postal Congress at Madrid in 1912. Another very interesting paragraph in the annual report is the reference to the special savings bank for children which was inaugurat-ed in 1905. A postal clerk goes round to all the principal schools in Cairo and Alexandria, takes the scholars' savings, and writes up their books after delivering and receiving money, et., just as it is done in the post-office. This system saves the children having to go to the post-office to effect their little economies. The report goes on to show that in all branches of the postal service the business has increased from 5 to 14 per cent in the lst year ; and finally, the postal receipts in 1906 are put down at 237,000 and the expenses at 185,000, giving 52,000 surplus. Next to Lord Cromer, the great Pro-Consul, few men have worked harder or more zealously for Egypt than Saba Pasha, and form all parts testimonials and expressions of high regard and regret are being tendered to the able Postmaster-General on his impending retirement.

div.head: AT THE RACES.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GASETTE"

Dear Sir,-The correspondence which has been going on lately under the above heading has been surely rather "instructive" than "amusing", as "Diogenes" evidently thinks. It has been instructive, in that it has shown us the exact moral standard of the majoirty of our fellow-countrymen in Alexandria who welcome these "undesirables" and cannot dis-tinguish between ladies of the full world and those of the "half world." This short sighted-ness is doubtless due to their greater familiar-ity with the latter type, owing to constant intercourse and associationi with them. These poor "ladies" are rightly described as "more sinned against than sinning," and it is doubt-less due to the fact that "Don Juan," "Impartial," "Diogenes" and company feel that they are the "sinners" that they feel it is only fair to take the side of the "sinned against." This is a very laudable sentiment. However there are some members and race-goers whohave a certain amount of respect for their wives and sisters, and for this small minority of Alexandrians I would suggest the formation of a member's enclosure at future meetings.-I enclose my card and beg to sign myself.
Yours truly

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Dear Sir, - Without wishing to prolong in any way the discussion in your columns of the question of the admission of "undesirables," to the grounds of the Alexandria Sorting Club, may I point out that the same evil exists at almost every race course in the world, and that the average man or woman of the world has long since learnt to shrug his or her shoulders at its existence. If you attempt to exclude persons as "undesirable" you must prove that the persons excluded are what they are accused of being at the time of their exclusion, your evidence must be convincing and derived, not from tittle-tattle or from merely circumstantial evidence supplied by rakish hats and artificial complexions, but from the testimony of un-impeachable witnesses. Now it seems to me that these witnesses will not be forthcoming in the majority of cases for obvious reasons, and anything like an attempt to exclude persons on insufficient testimony may well lead to libel actions. I cannot help thinking that a lady whose peculiarities of dress or manner caused her to be wrongfully excluded as an "undesir-able" from any public meeting place, would have an excellent case against her excluders. As for the question of morality, I fail to see why, as long as the women complained of be-have with decorum , that there should be any reason to exclude them. I grant that they frequently dress in appalling taste, but that is not an affair for the local censors, but if they conduct themselves with decency, why brand them for paying homage to the observances of society? They imitate and flatter their desirable and virtuous sisters who go to the races in smart frocks and I have never heard that virtuous sisters who go to the races in smart frocks and I have never heard that virtuous women were guaranteed like trademarks against counterfeits. As for the question of duty, surely no woman or man can really desire that their less fortunate fellow creatures should be given no chance whatever of harmless amusement and recreation, and for past errors or misfortunes be compelled to endure all the penalties of public outracism.

If you want to prevent people who have joined the "undesirable" class from ever re-habilitating their character, then by all means boycott them, prevent them from entering race courses, concert rooms, libraries, churches and good hotels, let them know that they are irretrievably lost, that by losing one virtue they have lost all claim to consideration, and you will certainly effect your object, and by crushing the last vestiges of their self-respect condemn them to a brutalised existence, ever on the down grade. Only you must not be surprised if such victims of your zeal show a strong dislike to be "reclaimed" or reformed, and a great disbelief in your assertion that you are indulging in these outbursts of moral vigour for their good or for the good of society. You brutalise and degrade them still further, and by adding to the sum total of degradation you degrade society, which cannot benefit from the existence of a class of outcasts. Lastly may I say that it seems to have been forhotten by some of your contributors that "charity" is a Christian virtue, and, if we are to attach any importance to. Holy Writ, is the higheset of human virtues and the most beneficial of all, in that it can raise even the lowest.-Yours, etc.
Cairene.

div.head: CAESARS CAmP.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GASETTE."

Sir,-It is really gratifying to see that the well known solicitor is at last having his well earned rest after the exciting time he passed through at Campo Cesare ; but at the same time it is so sad to see that his poor dear friend "Unsatisfied" cannot give up, a la Sarah Bernhardt, his trivial polemics.
Yours truly
div.note: (The Correspondence on Caesar's Camp must now cease. Ed. E.G.)

div.head:
C.B. AT PLYMOUTH.
ATTACK ON THE LORDS.
CHANCES OF DISSOLUTION

div.p: Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, speaking at Plymouth, said that Ireland must now wait and see what the Liberals were prepared to offer in the future. His speech, which was a lengthy one, was devoted to an attack on the the Lords. The time for compromise and temporising expostulation, he said, was past. We must give the Lords to understand that the people must be master of their own house. He urged the Liberals to keep the fighting line strong and unbroken. The existance of Liberalism as an instrument of progress de- pended upon the outcome of the struggle. It were better to the people in order to ascertain their rights than linger as teh shadow of a government, strong numerically, but without autority or power

It was surmised from Sir H. Campbell- Bannerman's speech at Plymouth that he did not see any reason for bustling into a general election. The Government would go straight forward regardless of abuse (Reuter)

Riots have occurred at St. Etienne. The So- cialists made a demonstration against M Briand who was there to unveil a statue, calling him a traitor : stones were thrown : many arrests were made. (Reuter)
500 unified socialists have hooted M. Briand. (Havas)
In his speech, Mr. Briand justified the programme of the Cabinet and condemned the electoral outbidding. (Havas)

div.head:
KING OF DENMARK.
VISIT TO LONDON.

div.p: The Kind and Queen of Denmark have arrived. They were welcomed at the station by King Edward and Queen Alexandra and drove in procession to Buckingham Palace. (Reuter)

France has offered her good offices to pro- mote a stable understanding between America and Japan. The State Departement is dubious regarding the possibility of putting the offer to practical use but received it in the cordial spirit in which it was made. It was added that the only negotiations likely to take place in th enear future will relate to an immigration treaty: Nothing had arisen to preclude direct dealing with reference to it. The San Francisco incident is regarded as closed from a diploma- tic point of view. (Reuter)
The Standard learns that the American Government has decided to decline France's offer. (Reuter)

A semi-official not esays that the statement that France has offered her good offices to America is incorrect. Nothing indicates that the relations between the United States and Japan necessitated her good offices, but it is true that there has been the friendliest parley- ing with the American Government concerning France's arrangement with Japan. (Reuter)
Havas's Agency denies that France has offered its good offices to the U.S.A. in regard to Japan. (Havas)
Grossemere has won the Grand Steeple- chase, (Havas)

div.head: PTOLEMAIC MONUMENTS.
div.byline: (From the Alexandria Correspondent of the Times," dated September 7, 1897.)
div.p: This morning saw Alexandria endowed; with an 'interesting monument, a relic of the Ptolemaic days. About 20 years ago there was discovered in the grounds of a Jewish school 'the shaft of a large handséme rosé' granite column ; this was presented to the Municipality by Baron Jacques Menasce but no use was made of it until quite recently. Dr. Schiess Bey, director of the Government, hos- pitol, offered to erect it on a prominent site ae ae from which it is' visible far out to sea, u himself the responsi- bility for all risks and expense.

By good fortane his excavations resulted in fi the capital almost uninjured at 30ft. distance from the shaft, The length of shaft is over 34 ft. witha diameter of 8} feet and weight 70 tons. 'The base, a separate piece, is 2 feet 4 inchesin height, by 5ft. Sin. diameter, and the capital, which consists of two pieces, is 4ft. Gin. in height by 7ft. 9 in. diagonai breadth. One side of it is.not carved, but has cuts made for inserting metal cramps, as thoggh it' were originally attached to a building, the capital gonsiderably overhanging the base of the column. The monument when completed will measure 55ft. 7in. from the ground to the summit. The column is believed to have belonged to the temple of Saturn which early in the fourth century was transformed into the:church of St. Michael.
The following inscription is on a scroll deposited in the pedestal of gray stone built. to support the column.

"This colamn was erected in commemoration of the fall of Omdurman and Khartum (Sept. 2 1898) a victory won by-the troops of Victoria, Queen,and Empress, fighting side by side with the soldiers of Abbas Hilmy, Khedive of Egypt. The gloriows success of the combined troops under General Kitchener, Sirdar of the Egyptian Army, resulting in the reconquest of, the Sudan and. the avenging of the death of Gordon Pasha, was rendered possible by the prosperity of Egypt, chiefly due to the wise counsels of the English Minister Plenipo- tentiary, Lord Cromer, and the hearty co- operation of English and Egyptian officials, Signed by Ronald B. Lane, Major-General Ambrose Ralli, Vice-President Alexandria Municipality ; Christophe de Tschudi, Dr. Armand 'Riiffer, President of!the . Sanitary Maritime and Quarantine Council; J. G. Chakour, Director General of the Municipality; Carlton Lieut Colonel, Richard M. Blomfield, Admiral ; Rosamund 8. Blomfield, Jacques de Menasce, Johannes Schiess von, Herisau Schweitz, H. Milton, E. B. Gould Consul- General Alexandria, and Rennell Rodd Acting British Minister Plenipotentiary.

A statue of Gordon would worthily crown the column, and Ihave been asked to. bring the suggestion to the notice of the friends of the late.General in the hope that they will approve of it and further it's execution, as there is no monument to his memory in this country, for which he did so much and finally gave his life.

Another monoment, also due to the initia tive of Dr. Schiess, is a beautifnl white marble column with a composite capital of green granite which he discovered during his ex- cavations in ground belonging to the Hibspital. This column he erected in 1897 to commem- orate the Queen's jubilee ; it stands on a knoll in the hospital garden overlooking the sea, and.bears on "the pedestal the following inscription
Victoriae
Britt. Reg. Fid. Def.
Ind. Imp,
IVN. XXII. A.D.
MDCCCXC VII.

Jt seems apity that the learned societies of England display little or no interest .in the Greek and Roman antiquities of Alexandria and the neighbourhood, where very much of great value still remains buried.
The city museum now contains a highly interesting collection, which, however, bunt few travellers stay to visit.

Nota Bene. It seems strange that Schiess Pasha should have on two occasions this shown his appreciation of the British rule in country, by erecting two columns at his own expense in this city, and yet has never received any token from the British au- thorities, here or in Downing Street, of these generous actions. We feel positive that if H.M. King Edward VIII was aware of such apparent ingratitude on the part of the British com- munity and of the Powers that be, His Majesty himself would rectify the oversight.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
FOURTH SUMMER MEETING.
div.p: Excellent weather favored the second day's racing of the Fourth Summer Meeting and the attendance 'was one of the best and most fashionable we have seen this season. Amongst those present we noticed Sir Eldon Gorst, Sir William Garstin, Rear Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield, Borton Bey, Hopkinson Bey and the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson. Racing and betting were keen, the chief interest of 'the afternoon being centred upon the Summer Handicap for which fifteen. runners went to the post and the Mahmoudieh Cup which brought out Carlton and Aurelius meeting at only a difference of 8.Jbs, and it was generally anticipated that the former would reverse the result of Thursday's running, but he was not game enough and Aurelius-won comfortably. The Band,of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers under the conduetorship of Band- master A. Fawcetéplayed during the afternoon.

div.head: FIRST RACE

Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50
